parts.text:
```json
{
  "application": "Spack",
  "details": {
    "scheduler": "Slurm",
    "spack_version": "0.17.2",
    "spack_instance_name": "cpu",
    "spack_instance_dir": "/cm/shared/apps/spack/0.17.2/cpu",
    "package": "netcdf-c@4.8.1",
    "compiler": "intel@19.1.3.304",
    "variants": "~dap ~fsync ~hdf4 ~jna ~mpi ~parallel-netcdf +pic +shared",
    "dependencies": "^hdf5@1.10.7/$(spack find --format '{hash:7}' hdf5@1.10.7 % ${SPACK_COMPILER} ~mpi)",
    "intel_license_file": "40000@elprado.sdsc.edu:40200@elprado.sdsc.edu",
    "resources": {
      "nodes": 1,
      "tasks_per_node": 1,
      "cpus_per_task": 16,
      "memory": "32G",
      "time": "00:30:00"
    }
  }
}
```

This script uses Spack, a package manager for scientific software, to install the `netcdf-c` package, version 4.8.1, on a Slurm cluster.  It uses the Intel compiler version 19.1.3.304 and specific variants for the `netcdf-c` package. It also depends on HDF5 1.10.7 and utilizes the Intel license file specified. The script requests specific resources on the cluster including 1 node, 1 task per node, 16 CPUs per task, 32GB of memory, and a maximum runtime of 30 minutes.  It also sets up environment variables for tracking execution time and system information, as well as providing details on the Slurm job itself.

The script first configures the environment, then uses Spack to install the specified netcdf-c package. It then runs a script for `netcdf-cxx4` with dependencies on the `netcdf-c` installation. Finally, it sleeps for 60 seconds.
